questions.text: 1. A 35-year-old female patient presents with postprandial epigastric pain, nausea, and vomiting. CT angiography revealed the compression of the celiac artery by the median arcuate ligament. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 35-year-old female patient presenting with postprandial epigastric pain, nausea and vomiting with CT angiography revealing compression of the celiac artery by the median arcuate ligament is suggestive of Dunbar syndrome.

Dunbar syndrome/ median arcuate ligament syndrome (MALS) is a vascular compression syndrome.

The celiac axis usually arises from the abdominal aorta between T11-L1, but this can vary greatly and the diaphragmatic crura arises from L1-L4. The median arcuate ligament is a band of fibrous tissue that connects the diaphragmatic crura anteriorly to the aortic hiatus. A lower diaphragmatic crura insertion or a higher celiac artery origin is likely to cause MALS. Sometimes median arcuate ligament crosses the lower abdominal aorta causing compression.

It is more common in females in the 3rd to 5th decade of life. Symptoms include postprandial symptoms including pain, nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea and unexplained weight loss.

CT angiography (CTA) aids in the diagnosis by enabling the visualization of the compressed celiac artery in 3D. Duplex ultrasonography can also be performed, but it is operator-dependent.

Treatment aims to decompress the celiac trunk using open, laparoscopic, or robotic methods in addition to adjuvant interventional procedures such as stenting and percutaneous transluminal angioplasty (PTA).



Other options:

Option A: Wilkie syndrome is associated with obstruction of the 3rd part of the duodenum due to the decreased angle between the superior mesenteric artery (SMA) and the aorta. 

Option B: May Thurner syndrome is associated with compression of the left iliac vein at the point where the right iliac artery crosses over it. It results in the development of iliofemoral deep venous thrombosis (DVT).

Option C: Nutcracker syndrome occurs due to compression of the left renal vein, between the aorta and the superior mesenteric artery. It presents with varicoceles and hematuria.

questions.text: 2. A young man is brought unconscious to the emergency department after a road traffic accident. On examination, his left pupil is dilated and the right pupil is normal. He also has a positive Babinski's sign in the left foot. Identify the most likely site of brain herniation leading to this presentation.
questions.solution:
The most likely site of brain herniation leading to this presentation is '3' (uncal herniation).

The given clinical scenario with a unilateral pupillary dilatation with signs of ipsilateral upper motor neuron (UMN) palsy [Babinski's sign positive], is suggestive of Kernohan's notch phenomenon, which can occur due to uncal herniation.

Herniation of the uncus (anterior medial temporal gyrus) from the supratentorial to the infratentorial region results in compression of the ipsilateral third cranial nerve. This results in pupillary dilatation of the same side (parasympathetic fibers are present superficially in the nerve).

As the herniation progresses, the contralateral midbrain and thus the contralateral cerebral peduncle gets compressed against the tentorial edge on that side. This presents as a UMN palsy of the same side as uncal herniation with a positive Babinski's sign. Normally the side opposite the herniation would be expected to show hemiparesis but when the same side shows hemiparesis as explained above, it is termed as Kernohan's notch.

Kernohan's notch is a false localizing sign because even though the herniation is on the ipsilateral side of the brain, the hemiparesis may present ipsilaterally because of compression of descending tracts on the opposite side. For example, a patient with left side herniation would be expected to present with right side paresis, but due to Kernohan's notch, he may present with left side paresis.

Subfalcine herniation (labeled 1) refers to the herniation of the cingulate gyrus under the falx cerebri. It presents initially with headache. Once it compresses the ipsilateral anterior cerebral artery it can result in contralateral lower limb weakness. This type of herniation does not involve the pupillary functions.

Central herniation/central transtentorial herniation(labeled 4) would present with the initial signs of mitotic pupils and drowsiness due to the downward displacement of the thalamic structures through the tentorial opening, resulting in compression of the upper midbrain. It can later progress to damage the pons and medulla as well.

Foraminal herniation (labeled 2) refers to the herniation of the cerebellar tonsils through the foramen magnum. This results in early compression of the medulla, leading to respiratory arrest and death.



Site of herniation Structures involved Presenting symptoms
Subfalcine

Cingulate gyrus

Pericallosal arteries

Leg weakness

No pupillary involvement
Uncal (lateral)

Oculomotor nerve

Cerebral peduncle

Posterior cerebral artery

Ptosis

Ipsilateral mydriasis

Contralateral(normal) or ipsilateral(false-localizing) hemiparesis

Decreased consciousness
Tectal (posterior) Superior colliculi

Bilateral ptosis

Upward gaze paralysis
Axial (central transtentorial)

Perforating branches from basilar artery

Midbrain, pons, medulla

Reticular formation

Decreased consciousness

Impaired eye movement

Cushing’s triad (hypertension, bradycardia, respiratory irregularity/apnea)
Tonsillar Medulla Cushing’s triad


Pearl PM1677: Intracranial Hypertension

Definition

Intracranial hypertension is pressure within the cranium above normal. Normal range of ICP is 5-15mm Hg. Levels above 20-25mm Hg are usually treated. 

Causes: Intracranial haemorrhage, brain tumors, head injury, meningitis, brain abscess, etc. 

Symptoms of raised ICT

* Cushing’s triad – hypertension, bradycardia and respiratory depression

* Headache, visual blurring due to papilloedema and abducent nerve palsy 

* Focal symptoms may arise due to the local effects in patients with mass lesions or due to herniation.

* Seizures

* Stroke

Investigations

* CT brain or MRI brain with gadolinium to rule out ICSOL 

* Lumbar puncture is contraindicated in the presence of raised ICT due to the risk of coning.

* Papilledema (as an indicator of ICT) should be ruled out before lumbar puncture.

Treatment

* Dexamethasone

* Ventriculotomy to remove CSF or ventriculoperitoneal shunt

* Decompressive craniectomy

* Surgical resection of ICSOL – by craniotomy or stereotactic radiosurgery

* Whole brain radiation for multiple metastases causing raised ICT

questions.text: 3. A 70-year old woman presents with frequent vomiting and a tender swelling noticed in the Scarpa's triangle. She also experiences pain along the anteromedial aspect of the thigh which is relieved by hip flexion. The likely etiology of this pain is the compression of :
questions.solution:
Compression of the geniculate branch of the obturator nerve is the likely etiology of the pain.

The given clinical scenario and examination findings are suggestive of an obturator hernia. The pain from her thigh is due to the compression of the anterior or geniculate branch of the obturator nerve. This is also known as the Howship-Romberg sign. The pain in the anteromedial aspect of the thigh is relieved by thigh flexion.

The obturator foramen is formed by the union of the pubis and ischium, anteroinferior to the acetabulum it is covered by a membrane that is pierced at the medial and superior border by the obturator nerve and vessel. Weakening of the membrane results in enlargement of the canal and formation of a hernia sac. Obturator hernia is also known as the skinny old lady hernia or French hernia. It occurs more commonly in thin, elderly, debilitated females.

Predisposing factors are:

* Women with a wider pelvis and a more triangular obturator canal

* Malnutrition

* Chronic constipation

* Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)

* Multiparity

* Ascites

* Kyphoscoliosis

It occurs through the obturator canal between the superior pubic ramus and the obturator membrane. The patients usually present with features of intestinal obstruction, which is often confirmed only on laparotomy. In a few cases, it is seen as a swelling in Scarpa's triangle deep to the pectineus muscle, with the limb kept in flexed and abducted position, and any movement of the limb results in pain. 

The swelling can be missed due to the covering by the pectineus muscle. It is detected through the obturator foramen on vaginal or rectal examination in a few cases. The chances of bowel obstruction and perforations from strangulation are high. 

Treatment involves surgery and repair of the hernial orifice. The defect is best closed by a mesh plug placed just next to the neurovascular bundle. If infected, broad ligament can be used as a plug. Adjunctively, laparoscopic TAPP repair can also be done.

questions.text: 4. A 22-year-old boy who recently had his femur operated on after a road traffic accident develops a sudden onset of chest pain and difficulty in breathing. The chest X-ray showed focal oligemia. Which of the following marked structures is affected in this condition?
questions.solution:
The affected structure is '3' (Pulmonary artery).

The given clinical features and the X-ray showing focal oligemia [Westermark sign] are suggestive of pulmonary embolism. This occurs due to a clot in the pulmonary artery. It can be identified as it arises from the right ventricle.

Pulmonary embolism refers to embolic occlusion of the pulmonary arterial system. Most patients present with pleuritic chest pain, dyspnoea, and tachypnoea. The classical clinical triad of sudden onset of chest pain, dyspnoea, and hemoptysis is present in only a few cases.

Chest X-ray signs related to pulmonary embolism include:

* Hampton's hump is a pleural-based, wedge-shaped opacity with the apex of the triangle pointed towards the occluding vessel or hilum and implies lung infarction. 

* Westermark sign is a chest X-ray finding in pulmonary embolism. It is defined by a hyperlucent area with decreased vascularity due to oligemia of the involved part of the lung.

The various structures identifiable in the given cadaveric specimen of the heart are shown below:



Pearl PM0584: Chest X Ray signs in pulmonary embolism

Westermark's sign: Focal area of oligemia (decreased vascular markings) distal to the embolism.



Hampton's hump: Peripherally placed wedge-shaped or dome-shaped opacity due to infarction of lung tissue.



Palla's sign: Increased size of the right descending pulmonary artery with a sausage-like appearance.



Fleishner sign: enlarged pulmonary artery.

Melting sign: an infarct shows rapid clearing in contrast to pneumonic consolidation.

McConnell's sign (indirect sign of PE seen in transthoracic echo): hypokinesis of the right ventricular free wall with normal motion of the right ventricle apex.

Knuckle or sausage’ sign: dilatation of the pulmonary artery, proximal to the embolus with collapse or constriction of the distal arteries resulting in an abrupt tapering of these arteries.  

Note - A normal chest X-ray does not rule out pulmonary embolism in a patient with unexplained acute tachypnea or hypoxemia.

questions.text:
5. A 6-year-old child with a history of repeated, multiple, long bone fractures is diagnosed with osteogenesis imperfecta. Which of the following structures contains the type of collagen that is defective in this disease?

* Tendon

* Basement membrane

* Elastic cartilage

* Skin

* Sclera
questions.solution:
The structures containing collagen type 1 are the tendon[1], skin[4], and sclera[5].

Osteogenesis imperfecta is a connective tissue disorder that occurs due to abnormal type 1 collagen production. Type 1 collagen is also present in the skin, tendons, and Sclera (1, 4, 5) apart from bones.

Type of collagen seen in various locations of the body:

* Type I collagen is seen in the bone, dermis, tendon, ligaments, fibrocartilage, and sclera of the eyeball.

* Type II collagen is seen in hyaline and elastic cartilage (Option 3) and the vitreous body of the eye and intervertebral disc.

* Type III collagen is seen in reticulin fibers, smooth muscle, endoneurium, arteries, uterus, kidney, spleen, and liver.

* Type IV collagen is seen in epithelial and endothelial basal laminae and basement membranes. (Option 2)

Pearl PM2260: Types of Collagen

Collagen subtypes    Location   

Associated disease 
Type 1

Dermis 

Bone 

Tendons 

Ligaments

Dentin

Cornea

Blood Vessels 

Scar tissue

Osteogenesis Imperfecta

 
Type 2

Cartilage 

Vitreous humor 

Nucleus pulposus

  Stickler syndrome
Type 3

Skin 

Lung 

Intestines 

Blood Vessels 

Bone marrow 

Lymphatics 

Granulation tissue

Ehler-Danlos syndrome  
Type 4

Basement membrane 

 		 Alport syndrome 
Type 7

Dermo-epidermal junction

 Epidermolysis bullosa acquisita

questions.text: 6. A 75-year-old man presented with a deformity of the left arm as shown in the below image. It is due to the rupture of the tendon of:

choices.text: Long head of the biceps brachii muscle
Short head of the biceps brachii muscle

questions.solution:
The given image shows Popeye's sign. It occurs due to the rupture of the tendon of the long head of the biceps brachii muscle.

Popeye sign appears due to the bulging of the muscle belly caused by contraction of the unrestrained muscles on flexing the elbow. The sign is named due to the resemblance of the deformity with the famous cartoon character 'Popeye'.

Biceps brachii is one of the muscles of the anterior compartment of the arm. It has two heads - a long head and the short head. The long head originates from the supraglenoid tubercle of the scapula whereas the short head originates from the apex of the coracoid process. Both heads get inserted into the radial tuberosity.



The biceps brachii muscle is innervated by the musculocutaneous nerve (C5, C6). It causes powerful flexion of the forearm at the elbow joint and supination of the forearm. It also is an accessory flexor of the arm at the glenohumeral joint. 

The rupture of muscles and tendons of the upper limb is usually uncommon, however, the long head of biceps brachii is the most commonly ruptured tendon. Rupture of the short head of biceps brachii  (Option D) is extremely rare due to its protected course. If it occurs, features include anterior shoulder pain, weakness in elbow flexion and forearm supination. 

Distal biceps tendon rupture (Option B) presents with a sudden “pop” at the elbow, pain, swelling, bruising in the antecubital fossa, weakness of elbow flexion and forearm supination, and the reverse Popeye sign (muscle belly retracted proximally). Confirmed by hook test or MRI.

The brachialis (Option A) is also a muscle in the anterior compartment of the arm. It originates from the anterior aspect of the humerus and inserts into the ulnar tuberosity. It is innervated by the musculocutaneous nerve (C5, C6) and radial nerve (C7). It is a strong flexor of the forearm at the elbow joint.

Pearl PM0034: Dermatome and root value of the upper limb



Key Sensory Areas:

* C5 - Upper lateral part of arm

* C6 - Palmar pad of thumb

* C7 - Pad of index finger

* C8 - Pad of little finger

* T1 - Skin on medial aspect of elbow

questions.text: 7. A woman with a history of 2 abortions undergoes an HSG which shows the presence of a bicornuate uterus. Defect in the development of which of the following structures leads to the given condition?
questions.solution:
Bicornuate uterus results from the defective development of the paramesonephric (Mullerian) duct.

The uterus and the cervix develop from the paramesonephric ducts (Mullerian ducts). The derivatives of the paramesonephric (Mullerian) ducts in the female include

* Uterine tube

* Uterus and cervix

* Upper part of vagina





Pearl PM1979: Derivatives of Mesonephric (Wolffian) duct and Paramesonephric (Mullerian) duct

Structures arising from mesonephric/Wolffian duct

Males Females
Ureteric bud and its derivatives Ureteric bud and its derivatives
Trigone of bladder Trigone of bladder
The proximal part of the prostatic urethra The posterior wall of the urethra
Spermatic pathway Gartner's duct
Appendix of epididymis  


Structures arising from the paramesonephric/Mullerian duct

Males Females
Appendix of testis Fallopian tube
Prostatic utricle Uterus
  Cervix
  Upper vaginal wall


Pearl PM1912: Mullerian Anomalies

 

Class Mullerian anomaly Reason/Feature Treatment Complications
I Uterine hypoplasia or uterine agenesis Underdeveloped or non-developed paramesonephric duct
  • Infertility treatment -surrogacy 
  • Vaginoplasty for vaginal hypoplasia
 Infertility

 
II Unicornuate uterus Non-developed paramesonephric duct Excision of rudimentary horn, if any  
  • Uterine rupture
  • Abortions
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
III Uterus didelphys Unfused paramesonephric duct

Metroplasty- Resection of membrane and fundal recombination. This can be:

  • Hysteroscopic
  • Open e.g., Strassman metroplasty
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
IV Bicornuate uterus  Lower part is fused whereas upper part is unfused Metroplasty in selected cases 
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
V Septate uterus  Septa of fused part persists Hysteroscopic septal resection 
  • Infertility
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
VI Arcuate uterus A small indentation at upper part    
VII Diethylstillbesterone (DES), drug related T-shaped uterus, shortened and narrow fallopian tubes, cervical collars (Cockscomb cervix)  
  • Ectopic pregnancy
  • Cervical incompetence
  • Clear cell adenocarcinoma of cervix and vagina


A common complication is an abortion in the second trimester.

Arcuate uterus: Some studies report no increase in adverse outcomes, whereas some studies have shown excessive second trimester loss, preterm labor and malpresentations.

questions.text: 8. On examination of cranial nerve reflexes, a patient is found to have a loss of light reflex, accommodation reflex, and gag reflex. Damage to the structures passing through which foramen can be ruled out?
questions.solution:
Damage to the hypoglossal nerve passing through the hypoglossal canal can be ruled out.

The hypoglossal nerve, passing through the hypoglossal canal, supplies all the intrinsic and extrinsic muscles of the tongue, except palatoglossus, and paralysis of this leads to deviation of the tongue towards the paralyzed side.

Other options:

Option B-Optic canal-optic nerve passes through the optic canal. It carries the afferents of both the light and accommodation reflex.

Option C-Jugular foramen-glossopharyngeal nerve[Ⅸ], vagal nerve[Ⅹ], accessory nerve[ⅩⅠ]pass through the jugular foramen. The afferent nerve for the gag reflex is the glossopharyngeal nerve, while the efferent nerve consists of both the glossopharyngeal (to the stylopharyngeus muscle) and vagus.  and damage to them may be the cause of loss of the gag reflex.

Option D-Superior orbital fissure-lacrimal and frontal nerve[ophthalmic nerve branches(Ⅴ1)], trochlear nerve passes through the lateral part. Nasociliary nerve[ophthalmic nerve branch]and abducent[Ⅵ], Occulomotor[Ⅲ] pass through the middle part. The occulomotor nerve carries efferent fibers of the light and accommodation reflex.

Pearl PM2228: Superior orbital fissure



Structures passing through the Superior orbital fissure

Above the common tendinous ring: LFT (Superolateral compartment)

* Lacrimal nerve

* Frontal nerve

* Trochlear nerve

* Superior ophthalmic vein

Within the common tendinous ring: BAN (Intermediate compartment)

* Both divisions of oculomotor nerve

* Abducens nerve

* Nasociliary nerve

Below the common tendinous ring (Inferomedial compartment)

* Inferior ophthalmic vein

Pearl PM2485: Structures passing through skull foramina

Opening Transmits
Optic canal
  • Optic nerves
  • Ophthalmic arteries
Superior orbital fissure
  • Lacrimal nerve (V1)
  • Frontal nerve (V1)
  • Nasociliary nerve (V1)
  • CNs III, IV, VI
  • Superior ophthalmic vein
  • Inferior ophthalmic vein
Foramen rotundum
  • Maxillary division of CN V (V2)
Foramen ovale
  • Mandibular division of CN V (V3)
  • Accessory meningeal artery
  • Lesser petrosal nerve
  • Emissary veins
Foramen spinosum
  • Middle meningeal artery
  • Nervus spinosus
  • Middle meningeal vein
Foramen lacerum
  • Deep petrosal nerve
  • Meningeal branch of ascending pharyngeal artery 
  • Emissary vein
Carotid canal
  • Internal carotid artery
  • Venous and sympathetic plexus around artery
Jugular foramen
  • Inferior petrosal sinus
  • Meningeal branch of ascending pharyngeal artery 
  • CNs IX,X & XI
  • Sigmoid Sinus continuing as IJV 
  • Middle meningeal branch of occipital artery
Hypoglossal canal
  • Hypoglossal nerve (CN XII)
Foramen magnum
  • Osseo-ligamentous (anterior) compartment: 
    • Apical ligament and tip of dens
    • Upper band of cruciate ligament
    • Membrana tectoria
  • Neuro-vascular (posterior) compartment:
    • Lower end of the medulla oblongata with meninges
    • Fourth part of vertebral artery surrounded by sympathetic plexus of nerves
    • Spinal roots of accessory nerves
    • Anterior and posterior spinal arteries
    • Tonsil of cerebellum.

questions.text: 9. An 18-year-old boy presents to the orthopedic unit with a cubitus valgus deformity. He gives a history of fracture at the elbow when he was a kid and showed the below radiograph that was taken at the time of fracture. Which of the following nerves will be at risk of palsy in this patient?
questions.solution:
The ulnar nerve will be at risk of palsy in this patient. 

The image shows lateral condyle fracture of the humerus. Non-union of this fracture results in cubitus valgus deformity. The cubitus valgus deformity leads to the stretching of the ulnar nerve resulting in classic neuropathic symptoms which is termed as tardy ulnar nerve palsy. Paresthesia in the ulnar nerve distribution with atrophy of the intrinsic hand muscles can be seen. It can be treated with ulnar nerve transposition and cubitus valgus correction.

Lateral condyle fractures usually occur between the age group 4-6 years and are due to fall on an outstretched hand that results in avulsion of the lateral condyle of the humerus. 

The elbow will be swollen and deformed with tenderness over the lateral condyle. Diagnosis is by the different views in a radiograph.

Treatment: An undisplaced fracture can be treated with a long-arm cast for 4-6 weeks and monitored closely for any late displacements. A displaced fracture should be treated with open reduction and internal fixation.

The lateral condylar fracture can lead to various complications including physeal arrest, physeal stimulation, osteonecrosis, and non-union with resultant cubitus valgus. Osteonecrosis of the capitellum results in a fish-tail deformity.



Other options: The anterior interosseous nerve, median nerve, and radial nerve injury are found in supracondylar fracture of the humerus.

Pearl PM2013: Three point bony relationship in elbow:

The three bony points in the elbow are :

* Tip of the medial epicondyle

* Tip of the lateral epicondyle

* Olecranon

When the elbow is in 90 degrees of flexion, these points form an isosceles triangle. When the elbow is extended, they lie transversely in a straight line.



The three-point bony relationship is maintained in the case of supracondylar fracture of the humerus as the fracture occurs above the level of these bony landmarks.

Conditions where it is distorted:

* Fracture medial condyle and epicondyle

* Fracture lateral condyle and epicondyle

* Intercondylar fracture of humerus

* Fracture olecranon

* Elbow dislocation

Pearl PM2014: Fractures of necessity

Fractures of necessity are those that require surgery for management. These include:

* Lateral condyle fracture humerus 

* Displaced fractured of olecranon and patella

* Fracture neck of femur

* Galeazzi fracture-dislocation 

* Monteggia fracture in adults

* Intra-articular fractures

questions.text: 10. A 55-year-old chronic alcoholic patient is diagnosed with early-stage hepatocellular carcinoma in the right lobe and is scheduled for a right hemi-hepatectomy. Which of the following segments have to be removed in the patient?
questions.solution:
In right hemi-hepatectomy (also called right hepatectomy), segments V, VI, VII, and VIII are removed. 

Cantlie’s line or main portal fissure extends from the midpoint of the gallbladder fossa at the inferior margin of the liver to the midpoint of the inferior vena cava. It divides the liver into the right and left hemiliver. It contains the middle hepatic vein. The liver has 3 major fissures and 3 minor fissures.

Couinaud classification is the commonly used classification of the liver. It divides the liver into eight segments. It is based on the distribution of portal venous branches in the liver parenchyma. Each segment has its own dual vascular inflow, biliary drainage, and lymphatic drainage.

The left lobe is composed of the left lateral segment (Couinaud’s segments II and III) and left medial segment (segment IV). The right lobe is composed of segments V, VI, VII, and VIII, with segments V and VIII making up the right anterior lobe and segments VI and VII making up the right posterior lobe. Couinaud's liver segments are as follows:



Segments removed in various liver surgeries:

* Right hepatectomy or right Hemi-hepatectomy - V, VI, VII, VIII (Option A)

* Right tri-sectionectomy or extended right hepatectomy - IV, V, VI, VII, VIII (Option B)

* Right anterior sectionectomy- V, VIII (Option C)

* Right posterior sectionectomy - VI, VII (Option D)

* Left hepatectomy or left hemi-hepatectomy - II, III, and IV

* Left tri-sectionectomy or extended left hepatectomy - II, III, IV, V, and VIII

* Left medial sectionectomy- IV

Pearl PM1159: Couinaud's liver segments

The Couinaud classification is currently the most widely used system to describe functional liver anatomy.

* Based on the distribution of hepatic portal venous branches in the parenchyma

* Each segment has its own dual vascular inflow, biliary drainage and lymphatic drainage

Segment I corresponds to the gross anatomical caudate lobe and is considered as posterior segment.

Other segments:

Liver sections

Couinaud's Segments

Right anterior sections

Segments V,VIII

Right Posterior sections

Segments VI, VII

Left medial sections

Segment IV (quadrate lobe)

Left lateral sections

Segment II, III

questions.text: 11. A 25-year-old man presents with shortness of breath and leg cramps. His blood pressure is found to be elevated in the upper extremities and decreased in the lower extremities. A chest X-ray taken during his initial workup is shown below. Which arteries are directly responsible for the given finding?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette indicates coarctation of aorta, and the given chest X-ray shows notching of the inferior margins of ribs. The arteries directly responsible for this finding are the intercostal arteries.

Coarctation of aorta results from congenital narrowing of aorta occurring just proximal, opposite, or distal to the ligamentum arteriosum attachment. Narrowing of the aorta leads to increased blood flow and enlargement of collateral posterior intercostal arteries, which cause rib notching. 

It is characterized by elevated blood pressure in the upper limbs and lower blood pressure in the lower limbs. The key clinical indicator is reduced/absent pulse in the femoral arteries.

The body compensates through extensive collateral circulation, causing dilatation of internal thoracic (Option D), subclavian, and posterior intercostal arteries. Notching of lower rib borders, visible on radiographs, results from erosion by dilated intercostal arteries.

Other options: 

Option A and C: Subcostal arteries and internal mammary arteries are not the primary contributors to collateral circulation in this condition.

Option D: Although internal thoracic arteries are dilated due to collateral circulation, rib notching is caused by intercostal arteries.

questions.text: 12. A multiparous woman has a previous history of birth trauma with injury to the marked ligament "X". According to DeLancey's classification, which level of uterine support is affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
According to DeLancey's classification, level 1 of uterine support is affected in this patient as the uterosacral ligament (marked "X") is injured. 

DeLancey introduced three-level systems of genital tract supports:

* Level I includes uterosacral and cardinal ligaments. Damage to these ligaments leads to uterine descent, enterocele, and vault prolapse.

* Level II includes pelvic fascia, paracolpos,arcus tendineus, pubocervical, and rectovaginal fascia. Damage to these structures leads to cystocele and rectocele.

* Level III includes levator ani muscle and its damage leads to urethrocele, gaping introitus, and deficient perineum.



Pearl PM1349: DeLancey's levels of support of the genital organs

Level of support Structures forming the support Consequence of damage
Level 1

The cardinal-uterosacral ligament complex provides apical attachment of the uterus and vaginal vault to the bony sacrum

Uterine descent

Vault descent

Enterocele
Level 2

Lateral attachments provide support to the middle part of the vagina. The anterior vaginal wall is attached laterally to arcus tendinous fascia pelvis and the posterior vaginal wall is attached laterally to the facia overlying the levator ani muscle. 

Cystocele

Rectocele
Level 3

The urogenital diaphragm (Deep perineal muscles & Perineal membrane) and the perineal body provide support to the lower part of the vagina. 

Urethrocele

Gaping introitus

Deficient perineum


Pearl PM1166: Supports of the uterus

A. Primary supports

* Muscular or active support of the uterus:

* Pelvic diaphragm

* Perineal body

* Urogenital diaphragm

* Ligamentous (fibromuscular or mechanical) support:

* Transverse cervical ligaments of Mackenrodt or cardinal ligament

* Uterosacral ligament

* Round ligament of the uterus

* Pubocervical ligament

* Uterine axis

B. Secondary supports formed by peritoneal ligaments:

* Broad ligament

* Uterovesical fold of peritoneum

* Rectovaginal fold of peritoneum

questions.text: 13. Below is the image of the cubital fossa. Which of the following two marked structures are tested in the modified Allen's test before taking blood for arterial blood gas analysis?
questions.solution:
Modified Allen's test is used to test the patency of the radial artery (B) and ulnar artery (C) before drawing a blood sample for blood gas analysis.

The radial and ulnar arteries together form the preliminary blood supply to the hand. Both arteries anastomose with each other in the hand, mainly via the superficial and deep palmar arches, and thus, inadequate flow in one can be compensated by the other. 

Modified Allen's test is performed before any procedures involving the Radial artery, such as arterial puncture for blood gas analysis, radial artery graft for CABG, before creation of an A-V fistula, etc., to identify the robustness of the collateral supply to the hand from the Ulnar artery. The test procedure is as follows:

* The patient is first asked to open and close their fist to help increase the drainage of blood from the hand.

* The ulnar and radial arteries are then compressed by the examiner simultaneously.

* The hand should be pale now.

* The compression is then released from the ulnar artery while maintaining pressure over the radial artery.

* If the hand flushes, it means that the ulnar blood supply is intact.

* This test is repeated in the same hand while releasing the radial artery first, while continuing to compress the ulnar artery.

questions.text: 14. While assisting with a laparoscopic appendectomy, you observe the resident using the peritoneal fold marked below as a guide while coagulating vessels in the mesoappendix. This anatomical landmark is the fold of _______.
questions.solution:
The Fold of Treves is an antimesenteric ileocecal fold of peritoneum used as a guide while coagulating vessels in the mesoappendix.

A clinical aid useful for detecting the location of the appendix through small abdominal incisions is the identification of the fold of Treves. It is an antimesenteric ileocecal fold of the peritoneum that marks the junction of the ileum and cecum. As it does not contain any vessels, it is referred to as the bloodless fold of Treves. It is also used as a guide to determine the extent of coagulation during an appendectomy. This prevents thermal injury to adjacent structures.



Other options:

Option A: The ligament of Treitz is part of the duodenojejunal junction and forms the line of demarcation for gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding. Upper GI bleeding refers to bleeding proximal to the ligament of Treitz, and lower GI bleeding refers to bleeding distal to the ligament of Treitz. 

Option B: Jackson Membrane is an adhesion from the right abdominal wall to the anterior tenia of the ascending colon.

Option C: Gerlach valves are mucosal folds covering the appendiceal orifice.

questions.text: 15. A 48-year-old man developed hoarseness of voice following thyroidectomy, when the nerve marked below was accidentally injured. On examination, the affected vocal cord was in a para-median position and did not move laterally during deep inspiration. This nerve injury has resulted in an impairment of the function of all of the following except?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the functions of the cricothyroid will not be impaired.

The given clinical history along with the gross image points towards a diagnosis of left recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy. All laryngeal muscles are supplied by the ipsilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN), except cricothyroid which is supplied by the superior laryngeal nerve (SLN). Both SLN and RLN are branches of the vagus nerve.

The recurrent laryngeal nerves (RLN) on the right and the left side follow different courses-

* Right RLN takes origin in the root of the neck, winds around the first part of the subclavian artery, and then ascends in the tracheoesophageal groove. 

* Left RLN takes origin in the thorax, winds around the arch of the aorta, and then ascends in the tracheoesophageal groove. Since it has a longer course, it is more likely to be injured.

In case of RLN injury during surgery, if both ends are identified, they should be reanastomosed. If a length of the nerve has been excised during surgery, anastomosis with ansa cervicalis maybe considered. This does not return the mobility of the vocal cords, however neurological input is maintained.

In unilateral RLN palsy, the normal vocal cord crosses the midline and comes closer to the paralyzed one during speech output, as a compensatory measure. This improves the voice over time without any surgical intervention. However, in the case of a persistent defect after a wait of 6-12 months, a type 1 laryngoplasty maybe considered.



Pearl PM1978: Muscles of larynx

Remember 2 exceptions:

* All muscles are adductors, except PCA (an abductor)

* All muscles are supplied by the recurrent laryngeal nerve, except cricothyroid (superior laryngeal nerve)

Action
Muscle
Opening of the inlet of larynx
Thyroepiglotticus
Closing of the inlet of larynx
Aryepiglotticus, Interarytenoids
Abductor of vocal cords
Posterior cricoarytenoid
Adductor of vocal cords
Lateral cricoarytenoid
Tensor of vocal cords
Cricothyroid
Relaxer of vocal cord
Thyroarytenoid
Modulator of larynx
Vocalis


Safety muscle of larynx: Posterior cricoarytenoid

Safety muscle of tongue: Genioglossus

The muscle of whispering: Lateral cricoarytenoid

Vocalis is known as the modulator of larynx because, the anterior part of the vocalis muscle can tense the vocal cord, and its posterior part can relax the vocal cord.

Pearl PM1094: Various Vocal Cord Palsies

Type of palsy U/L Abductor B/L Abductor U/L complete B/L complete
Nerve RLN (left) Both RLNs RLN+SLN (left) Both RLN+SLN
Cord position Paramedian   |\ Both in  Paramedian   || Cadaveric   [\ cadaveric (intermediate) position [[
Voice Hoarse Good Hoarse Aphonia
Dyspnea - + - -
Aspiration - - +/- +
Treatment Wait & watch (palsy with least consequences) Tracheostomy, lateralization Wait & watch, medialization Tracheostomy + Epiglottopexy


Guide: \ is normal moving cord; | is paramedian; [ is cadaveric.

questions.text: 16. Optic nerve injury following functional endoscopic sinus sinus surgery (FESS) is due to the removal of which of the following ethmoidal cells?
questions.solution:
Optic nerve injury following sinus surgery (FESS) is due to the removal of Onodi cells.

Onodi cell is the posterior ethmoidal cell, related superiorly or laterally to the sphenoid sinus. The optic nerve lies in its lateral wall and can be injured while operating in the cells.



Option A: Haller cells are a type of anterior ethmoidal cells that are situated on the roof of the maxillary sinus.



Option B: Agger nasi is an anterior ethmoidal cell that is present in the agger nasi ridge.



Option D: Bulla ethmoidalis is the ethmoidal cell situated behind the uncinate process and forms the posterior boundary of hiatus semilunaris through which the maxillary, frontal and anterior ethmoidal sinuses drain.

questions.text:
17. A patient is diagnosed with a posterior mediastinal paraganglioma. The surgeon decides to approach the tumour from the posterior aspect using VATS. Which of the following anatomical structures is he least likely to encounter during the resection?

VATS: Video- assisted thoracoscopic surgery
questions.solution:
As the tumour is located in the posterior mediastinum, so during the procedure, the surgeon would not encounter inferior vena cava which is located anteriorly in the middle mediastinum.

The descending thoracic aorta, esophagus, and thoracic duct are all located in the posterior mediastinum.

Definitive treatment of posterior mediastinal paraganglioma is by complete surgical excision (gold standard) usually by VATS (Video-Assisted Thoracoscopic Surgery) or open thoracotomy depending on size/ location/ vascularity.

Surgical approaches for mediastinal tumor resection are determined by the tumor's anatomical location. Anterior mediastinal pathology typically requires a median sternotomy. For posterior mediastinal pathology, thoracotomy or VATS are generally used. Superior mediastinal tumors are approached via transcervical (neck) incisions. The middle mediastinum can usually be accessed through thoracotomy or VATS.

VATS (Video-Assisted Thoracoscopic Surgery): A minimally invasive surgical technique using a thoracoscope and small ports to access the chest cavity. It reduces pain, hospital stay, and complications compared to open thoracotomy. Commonly used for lung biopsies, lobectomy, pleural disease, and mediastinal procedures.

Tumors of posterior mediastinum- 

1. Neurogenic tumors (most common, esp. in adults & children)

*

Schwannoma

*

Neurofibroma

*

Ganglioneuroma

*

Neuroblastoma (children)

*

Paraganglioma

2. Esophageal tumors

*

Esophageal carcinoma

*

Esophageal leiomyoma

3. Other rare tumors

*

Gastroenteric cysts

Pearl PM2386: Divisions and contents of the mediastinum



Major contents of thoracic cavity
Superior mediastinum
  • Trachea
  • Esophagus
  • Thoracic duct
  • Thymus
  • Vessels-
    • Aortic arch
    • Left common carotid artery
    • Left subclavian artery
    • Brachiocephalic trunk
    • Right and left brachiocephalic veins
    • Superior vena cava (upper half)
    • Azygos vein near its opening into superior vena cava
  • Left recurrent laryngeal nerve
Inferior mediastinum Anterior
  • Thymus (inferior extension)
  • Mediastinal branches of internal thoracic vessels
  • Sternopericardial ligaments
Middle
  • Heart
  • Phrenic nerve
  • Tracheal bifurcation and bronchi
  • Roots of great vessels
    • Ascending aorta
    • Superior vena cava (lower half)
    • Inferior vena cava
    • Pulmonary trunk and branches
    • Pericardiophrenic arteries and veins
Posterior
  • Thoracic aorta
  • Thoracic duct
  • Esophagus
  • Vagus nerve
  • Azygos vein
  • Hemiazygos vein

questions.text: 18. A researcher was studying the symptoms of COVID-19 infection. He found that temporary loss of function of the sustentacular cells of the olfactory epithelium is implicated in anosmia. Which of the following accurately describes these cells?
questions.solution:
The sustentacular cells are supporting cells of the olfactory epithelium.

The nuclei of these cells are oval and lie near the free surface of the epithelium. The free surface of each cell bears numerous microvilli which are embedded in overlying mucous. The cytoplasm contains a yellow pigment termed lipofuscin that gives olfactory mucosa its yellow color. 

Sustentacular cells also may be phagocytic, and the pigment in them may represent remnants of phagocytosed olfactory cells. These cells also secrete mucus that provides the appropriate molecular and ionic environment for odor detection in the olfactory epithelium.

Other options:

Options B and C: Olfactory cells or olfactory receptor cells are modified neurons and each has a rounded nucleus in the central part. 

Option D: Basal cells lie deep in the epithelium and will not reach the luminal surface. They divide to replace olfactory cells to replace those that die.

questions.text: 19. A 50-year-old woman came to the OPD with a history of a lump in the right breast. On further evaluation, the size of the lump is found to be 5 × 6 cm and she is also noted to have right interpectoral axillary lymphadenopathy. These enlarged lymph nodes belong to ___________

choices.text: Level 1 group of axillary lymph nodes
Level 3 group of axillary lymph nodes
Level 2 group of axillary lymph nodes

questions.solution:
Interpectoral lymph nodes are classified under level 2 (deep) group of axillary lymph nodes.

Lymph nodes are divided into different levels on the basis of their relation to the pectoralis minor.

* Level 1 lymph nodes: Lateral to the pectoralis minor (anterior, lateral, and posterior/subscapular groups)

* Level 2 lymph nodes: Superficial or deep to the pectoralis minor (central and interpectoral groups)

* Level 3 lymph nodes: Medial to the pectoralis minor (apical/subclavicular group)

questions.text: 20. Which of the following structure is not a component of Mickey mouse sign in B-mode duplex scan?
questions.solution:
The External iliac artery is not a component of the Mickey mouse sign in B-mode duplex scan of the lower limb.

Mickey mouse sign is seen in the B mode duplex scan in the groin region. Mickey mouse sign is due to the great saphenous vein, common femoral vein, common femoral artery, and saphenofemoral junction.

The Mickey Mouse sign is a crucial anatomical landmark for vascular procedures involving the lower extremity, including venous access, diagnostic evaluations, and surgical interventions. Its recognition facilitates precise blood flow measurement, accurate placement of catheters and other devices, and a reduced risk of complications.

A distinct Mickey Mouse appearance can also be seen when a dilated accessory saphenous vein (ASV) exists: the common femoral vein (CFV) represents the head of Mickey Mouse while the great saphenous vein (GSV) and the dilated accessory saphenous vein (ASV) represent the ears.



Common Indications of USG Groin include hernia evaluation, vascular procedures, evaluation of lymph nodes, and soft tissue masses.
